newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - Unions say govt labour bill will be changed.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - Unions say govt labour bill will be changed.

text.p: Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) president Jennie George said on Monday she expected the government's workplace relations bill to be substantially amended in the upper house Senate.
George said this would seriously damage the government's attempts to weaken the current industrial relations system.
"I do not believe that the bill will pass through the Senate in its present form," George told a Retailers Association Conference in Sydney. A copy of her remarks was released here.
"The Greens and the two independent Senators have committed themselves to opposing substantial weakening of current protections," she said.
The Australian government needs two extra votes to pass any legislation in the Senate and is currently negotiating with the Democrats in the hope of winning their support.

"Although the Democrats have clearly stated that they expect the bill to pass this year, I am confident that (Democrats leader) Cheryl Kernot and her colleagues will maintain their policy commitment to a fair and balanced industrial relations system," George said.
The government's reforms would promote direct work contracts between workers and employers without unions or labour tribunals.
